properties.name: Alki Point Monument, "Birthplace of Seattle"
properties.description: Monument marking the place where the first white settlers, the Denny party, landed in 1851. With resources and aid from Chief Si'ahl, the Denny party built a settlement lasting for three years.

properties.name: Blue Moon Tavern
properties.description: Former haunt of poets Theodore Roethke, Richard Hugo, David Wagoner, Caroline Kizer, and many other writers. It’s now a music venue and bar.

properties.name: Daybreak Star Indian Cultural Center
properties.description: Major community center for Native American cultural activities featuring the work of artist Lawney Reyes.

properties.name: Duwamish Longhouse and Cultural Center
properties.address: 4705 W Marginal Way SW, Seattle, WA 98106
properties.description: Community center promoting the social, cultural, and economic survival of Seattle’s Duwamish Tribe.

properties.name: Duwamish Story Pole
properties.description: 25-foot story pole carved by Duwamish artist Michael Halady, a descendant of Chief Si’ahl, to honor and celebrate the Duwamish people.

properties.name: həʔapus Village Park
properties.description: Important Duwamish archaeological, cultural, ecological, and ancestral site sitting on the shores of one of the last remaining original bends of the Duwamish River.

properties.name: Lakeview Cemetary
properties.description: This cemetery is the burial place of many well-known Seattleites, including poet Denise Levertov, Princess Angeline – daughter of Chief Si'ahl, and Bruce and Brandon Lee.

properties.name: Log House Museum
properties.description: Museum home to the Southwest Seattle Historical Society and featuring the monthly series, “Words, Writers, and Southwest Stories.”

properties.name: Panama Hotel and Tea House
properties.description: National Historic Landmark representing Japanese immigration and incarceration featured in Jamie Ford’s bestselling novel Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet.

properties.name: Space Needle
properties.description: Iconic landmark featured in several books including the picture book Wheedle on the Needle and the novel Truth Like the Sun.

properties.name: wǝɫǝbʔaltxʷ (Intellectual House)
properties.description: Gathering space for American Indian and Alaska Native students, faculty, staff, and others from various cultures and communities to come together in a welcoming environment to share knowledge.
